column12: of natural language documents with a strong but hidden structure. This
column13: structure will then be converted into additional features (through
column14: tree kernels for example) in our analytics pipeline or alternatively
column15: as a starting template for existing multilingual authoring tools.

column24: ESWC is a A rank conference according to CORE classification and a major venue for discussing the latest scientific results and technology innovations related to the Semantic Web. The 11th edition of ESWC will take place from May 25th, 2014 to May 29th, 2014 in Anissaras, Crete, Greece. Besides a main focus on advances in Semantic Web research and technologies, ESWC 2014 is seeking to broaden its attention to span other relevant research areas in which Web semantics plays an important role.
column25: The goal of the Semantic Web is to create a Web of knowledge and services in which the semantics of content is made explicit and content is linked to both other content and services. This arrangement of knowledge-based functionalities is weaving together a large network of human knowledge, and making this knowledge machine-processable to support intelligent behaviour by machines. Additionally, it supports novel applications allowing content from heterogeneous sources to be combined in unforeseen ways and support enhanced matching between users needs, software functionalities and online content.
column26: Creating such an interlinked Web of knowledge which bridges between heterogeneous content and services requires collaboration between several computer science domains. Also, within this hybrid space that the Web has become, where humans and software interact in a complex manner, fundamentally requires an inter-disciplinary approach to find novel solutions to the problems generated.
column27: ESWC 2014 will feature twelve thematic research tracks (see below) and an in-use and industrial track. Submissions of interdisciplinary research papers, covering more than one thematic track, are also encouraged. In addition, the in-use and industrial track will provide an opportunity for dialogue and discussion on industrial applications, tools, deployment experiences, case studies and usage analysis.
column28: Submitted papers should describe original work, present significant results, and provide rigorous, principled, and repeatable evaluation. We strongly encourage and appreciate the submission of papers incorporating links to data sets and other material used for evaluation as well as to live demos and software source code.
column29: We therefore encourage submissions addressing several conference research topics. However, each paper should be associated with at least one of the topics of the conference. The main research topics this year are:

column5: An 18 months-funded position is immediately available for a highly motivated postdoctoral researcher to work in the group of Brice Felden, in the school of pharmacy of the University of Rennes 1 (France). Current research in the lab (INSERM U835) includes the study of bacterial regulatory RNAs and their function. The research unit focuses on the study of Staphylococcus aureus, an opportunistic pathogen responsible for nosocomial infections.
column7: The fellow will analyze NGS DNA-seq and RNA-seq data in order to study the transcriptome (with primary interested on RNA regulators) of clinical strains isolated from sepsis and septic shock and to identify the molecular primary targets of Staphylococcal regulatory RNAs (sRNAs) by pulse expression of a sRNA in knock-out strains already available in the lab. The candidate will perform de novo DNA sequencing to map RNA reads onto the genome of each clinical isolates. RNAseq data will be analyzed by differential analysis of data obtained in control conditions versus conditions miming a Staphylococcal infection.
column8: The candidate will work closely with Dr. Yoann AUGAGNEUR, an Assistant Professor in the department. He will be strongly encouraged to use Galaxy platform or to implement programs onto Galaxy platform for enhanced interaction with other members of the lab which are not familiar with the analysis of NGS data. column19: The ESWC 2014 PhD Symposium is a chance for PhD students working in all areas of Semantic Web research to present their work, meet with peers and experienced researchers, obtain feedback and learn from each other's experiences. It aims at helping future researchers in building up the skills and confidence required to conduct and promote their research, as well as providing them with an opportunity to attend one of the most important research conferences on the Semantic Web.
column21: The ESWC PhD Symposium will give to students the opportunity to:
column22: 1. Learn from a mentor: Established researchers and PhD student advisors will provide direct feedback. Each selected student will be assigned a member of the programme committee with whom they will interact on the revision of the paper and the preparation of the presentation.
column23: 2. Learn about research in general: Doing good research goes beyond writing a good paper
column24: it includes perspectives on research as an endeavour and a career. Besides the presentations, coffee breaks and the PhD Symposium lunch will be used to exchange ideas and ask questions about all aspects of conducting a PhD and a research career in general.
column25: 3. Learn by constructive criticism: Thinking and writing about strengths and weaknesses of other research contributions shapes your own research capabilities.  As a participant to the PhD symposium, you will be expected to also review submissions from others, allowing you to juxtapose and learn from convergence and divergence of opinions.
column26: 4. Learn by presenting: Accepted contributions will be presented in the PhD symposium. All accepted contributions will also appear at the general poster session of ESWC. Students' posters will be presented alongside posters and demonstrations of the main conference.
column28: Submissions will be considered from two different categories depending on the advancement into the PhD:
column29: - Early Stage PhD: For students who may have identified the main research problem they want to address, the relevant literature, and are building their research methodology, but might not yet have obtained significant results, or only preliminary ones.
column30: - Late Stage PhD: For students who have already defined their approach (even if incompletely) and obtained significant results (e.g., that might already have been published).
column31: These categories do not affect the chances of being selected. They will however be taken into account by reviewers in their feedback, and in the length and format of the presentation. The organisers might decide to move a submission from one category to the other, if they think it is justified.
column32: *Submission Information*
column33: PhD students in all areas of Semantic Web research are invited to submit papers having 5 to 10 pages describing their PhD research, in the PDF format following the LNCS template (http://www.springer.com/computer/lncs?SGWID=0-164-6-793341-0) Submissions should be sent using the PhD Symposium submission system (https://www.easychair.org/conferences/?conf=eswc2014ps), through which participants will be also asked to decide on the category of their submission and to write a paragraph regarding their motivation for participating in the ESWC PhD Symposium.
column35: Submissions should follow the following template of sections:
column37: 1. Introduction/Motivation
column38: Give a general introduction to the domain/area/topic and indication of its importance/impact in Semantic Web research or other domains.
column39: 2. State of the Art
column40: Describe existing work in the area, work focusing on the same/similar problems or that might be useful to realising your PhD.
column42: Based on motivation and state of the art, formulate the problem you intend to solve, and how you intend to contribute to Semantic Web research. This section should include a clear formulation of one (or very few) research hypothesis (what you will validate through your methodology, approach and evaluation) and the research questions that need to be answered. Late Stage PhD submissions should focus on contributions to such a hypothesis.
column43: 4. Research Methodology and Approach
column44: Describe the research methodology you will apply in your research, including the different steps from the formulation of your research questions to answering them. Also describe the approach you are taking (or you intend to take for Early Stage PhD submissions) to instantiate the research methodology, hence contributing to solve the problem described in Section 3 and confirm or reject your hypothesis. Discuss how this approach is innovative and novel, and how it is (might be) implemented.
column45: 5. Preliminary or Intermediate Results
column46: In a full conference paper, the approach would be fully described (in section 4) and fully evaluated (in section 6). Being at an intermediate stage, you should report here about the results achieved up to now in applying your approach that might not yet be sufficient for a full evaluation. .
column48: Describe your evaluation plan, which is the way you intend to validate your hypothesis, your results, and the value of your approach. For Early Stage PhD submissions, this might be only partially defined, and details might be ommited. For Late Stage PhD submissions, you might have partial evaluation results.
column50: Describe how your results will or might impact research or the world at large.

column7: Afin d'étudier l'évolution des génomes de plantes et d'animaux, la synténie (conservation des gènes entre espèces) et les duplications totales de génomes sont étudiées. En comparant les génomes séquencés d'espèces modernes animales et végétales l'équipe PaleoEvo (Paléogénomique et Evolution) de l'INRA de Clermont-ferrand (http://www4.clermont.inra.fr/umr1095/Equipes/Recherches/Paleogenomique-des-plantes-pour-l-amelioration-varietale) a défini un ancêtre à 5 chromosomes chez les Monocots, 7 chez les Dicots et 10 chez les vertébrés permettant de retracer l'histoire évolutive génomique des plantes et des animaux au niveau structural (Murat et al. 2012). L'équipe s'intéresse également à des aspects fonctionnels des gènes et de régulation des génomes liés à l'évolution, notamment concernant l'impact des duplications totales de génomes sur l'expression/méthylation des gènes dupliqués au sein des génomes modernes. Dans ce sens, l'équipe s'investit de façon importante dans le développement d'outils et de méthodes permettant de mettre en évidence des relations d'homologies entre et au sein des génomes de plantes et d'animaux afin de reconstruire leurs ancêtres et de comprendre leurs histoires évolutives.
column8: A ce jour, le travail de mise en évidence de ces relations de synténie et de paralogie chez les plantes et les animaux séquencés a été effectué et publié (cf liste publication jointe). L'objectif du stage est d'étudier différents méthylomes chez les plantes et les animaux afin de comprendre et de comparer les modes de régulation de ces génomes ainsi que de comprendre certaines différences génomiques entre les plantes et les animaux tel que la présence ou l'absence de chromosomes sexuels. Sur la base des travaux de l'équipe, le stagiaire devra assimiler les concepts ainsi que les différents outils et méthodes utilisés par l'équipe afin de centraliser toutes les connaissances nécessaires à ce travail, il devra mettre en place une méthode afin d'étudier ces méthylomes (data mining, mapping, interprétation, ...) et l'automatiser. Le développement de programmes sera donc également indispensable pour répondre aux objectifs.
column10: Maîtrise de langages de programmation (C, perl, JAVA, SQL, PHP...) ainsi que des outils d'interfaçage (HTML, CGI MySQL, PHP, perl CGI) appliqués aux systèmes d'exploitation classiques (IRIX, Linux, SOLARIS, OSF1, MacOS X). Exploitation des séquences (comparaison de séquences, utilisation de banque de données biologiques, alignements multiples, détection/annotation de gènes/repeat, phylogénie...). Maîtrise des techniques de sélection, exploration, modification et modélisation de grandes bases de données (Access...). Méthodes statistiques (régression, AFCM, ACP, analyse discriminante,  classification, test de permutation). Visualisation des données.

column13: L'UFIP abrite également une plateforme technologique IMPACT (Interactions Moléculaires Puces ACTivités), appartenant au réseau de plate-formes du Grand-Ouest en Sciences du vivant et de l'Environnement (Biogenouest)

column13: AIMS and SCOPE
column14: Cellular Automata are a well-known formal tool for modeling complex
column15: systems
column16: they are found in many scientific fields and industrial
column17: applications. Synchronous updating is one of the main features of Cellular
column18: Automata. Indeed, in the most common Cellular Automata framework, all
column19: cells are updated simultaneously at each discrete time step.
column20: Recent trends consider the modeling of asynchronous systems based on local
column21: interactions. The aim of this workshop is to bring together researchers
column22: dealing with the theme of the asyncrony inside Cellular Automata and other
column23: Discrete Models such as discrete Multi-Agents Systems, Boolean Networks,
column24: and so on,in order to foster their interaction and to provide a forum for
column25: presenting new ideas and works in progress on the subject.
column26: Topics include, but are not limited to the following aspects of
column27: Asynchronous Cellular Automata and Asynchronous Discrete Models (such as
column28: Multi-Agents Systems, Boolean Networks and so on):
column29: - dynamics
column30: - complexity issues
column31: - computational issues
column32: - emergent properties
column33: - models of parallelism and distributed systems
column34: - models of phenomena from biology, chemistry, physics, engineering and

column3: Subject: [bioinfo] Stage Master Biostat Montpellier
column4: SUJET:
column5: Analyse statistique comparative des transcriptomes de stades embryonnaires équivalents de trois espèces d'Ascidies
column7: L'équipe de Patrick Lemaire (CNRS, Montpellier, France
column8: (http://www.aniseed.cnrs.fr/lemaire) cherche à comprendre l'évolution du développement des embryons d'une classe d'animaux marins proches parents des vertébrés, les ascidies (tuniciers). L'équipe est composée de biologistes et de bio-informaticiens et est localisée au Centre de Recherche de Biochimie Macromoléculaire (CRBM), à Montpellier.
column10: Le but du stage est de comparer la dynamique et de quantifier la divergence des profils d'expression embryonnaires des gènes de 3 espèces d'ascidies séparées par plusieurs centaines de millions d'années d'évolution. Nous chercherons en particulier à déterminer si cette divergence à une structure temporelle (c-à-d si elle est minimale à un stade particulier de l'embryogénèse), et si la fonction des gènes influe sur l'évolution de leurs profils d'expression.
column11: Le/La stagiaire travaillera sur l'analyse des résultats obtenus à partir de séquençage à haut débit des ARNm (RNASeq) de 6 stades développementaux équivalents de trois espèces (Ciona intestinalis, Phalusia mammillata et Halocyntia roretzi) dont le génome a été séquencé et annoté.
column12: A partir d'un taux d'expression normalisé calculé à partir des données de RNA-seq pour chaque gène de chaque espèce à chaque stade du développement, le/la stagiaire développera des méthodes statistiques appropriées pour comparer ces profils entre espèces en prenant en compte à la fois les niveaux d'expression par stade et la dynamique d'expression au cours du développement.
column13: PROFIL ET COMPETENCES RECHERCHEES:
column14: Ce stage de niveau master est principalement destiné à des étudiants ayant une formation initiale en statistique, et ayant une bonne pratique du développement informatique. Les candidat(e)s devront avoir l'esprit d'équipe et savoir faire preuve d'autonomie, de dynamisme et de créativité. Des connaissances de base en biologie seraient bienvenues mais ne sont pas essentielles, une bonne curiosité pour la biologie est suffisant. La maîtrise de l'anglais technique doit être suffisante pour écrire des documentations techniques, et interagir quotidiennement à l'oral.
column16: Les compétences requises en informatique et statistique sont:
column17: - Languages de programmation : perl/python/C(ou C++), R.
column18: - Tests statistiques paramétriques et non paramétriques, méthodes d'analyses multifactorielles.
column19: Une certaine familiarité avec les méthodes d'analyse des données de RNASeq serait un plus, mais ne constitue pas un prérequis.
column20: DUREE et modalités du stage:
column21: 5-6 mois. Les stages sont gratifiés.
